document: This document covers the Medium Access Control (MAC) sublayer (hubs, bridges, switches, and VLANs)  and the Network Layer, including store-and-forward packet switching, connectionless vs. connection-oriented services, routing algorithms (Shortest Path, Flooding, Distance Vector, Link State, Hierarchical, Broadcast, Multicast), congestion control, fragmentation, and IP addressing (IPv4, IPv6, and ICMP).

questions.question: At which layer of the OSI model does a Hub operate?
A Hub is essentially a:
What happens when a Hub receives a bit on one of its ports?
options: It sends it to the destination MAC
It broadcasts it to all other ports
questions.answer: It broadcasts it to all other ports

questions.question: How do all ports on a Hub share bandwidth?
options: Bandwidth is shared among all active ports
Bandwidth is doubled for each port
questions.answer: Bandwidth is shared among all active ports

questions.question: Distance Vector Routing is also known as the:

questions.question: What is the 'Count-to-Infinity' problem?

questions.answer: A problem where routing loops cause distance metrics to increase indefinitely

questions.question: In Distance Vector Routing, 'Good news travels fast, but bad news travels slowly' refers to:

questions.answer: Fast convergence when a link comes up, slow when it goes down
